questions.text: A patient is in a hypervolemic hyponatremia state and Urinary Na is found to be >20 mmol. Which of the following may lead to this finding?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Acute renal failure Hypervolemic hyponatremia - An increase in total-body Na & Cl, that is accompanied by a proportionately greater increase in total-body water, leading to hyponatremia Lab report showing Urine Na > 20mM The Sodium-avid edematous disorders (Urine Na+ is typically very low < 10mM) include: Congestive heart failure [CHF] Cirrhosis Nephrotic syndrome In hypervolemia Urine Na > 20 → Renal failure (Both Acute and chronic) Hence this patient is suffering from Renal failure likely Acute.

Highyeild:

In hypervolemia Urine Na < 20 → CHF, Cirrhosis , Nephrotic syndrome

Extraedge:

The degree of hyponatremia is an important prognostic indicator in hypervolemic hyponatremia.

questions.text: Euvolemic hyponatremia implies normal sodium stores and a total body excess of free water. This occurs in patients who take in excess hypotonic fluids. Which of the following is the most frequent cause of Euvolemic hyponatremia?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

SIADH Euvolemia is the state or condition of having the normal volume of blood or fluids in the body with the absence of edema Mild increase in water content with an almost normal level of absorption of sodium à Euvolemic hyponatremia Euvolemic hyponatremia can occur in the conditions listed below in the table. Correction occurs after correcting the underlying abnormality. SIADH is the most frequent cause of euvolemic hyponatremia Hyponatremia results from an increase in circulating AVP and /or increased renal sensitivity to AVP , combined with an intake of free water AVP preserves Blood pressure via vascular and baroreceptor V1A receptor Increases water reabsorption via renal V2 receptors

Highyeild:

Osmotic threshold and osmotic response curves for the sensation of thirst are shifted downward in patients with SIADH Hypothyroidism is also a less common cause wherein Euvolemic hyponatremia is correct after achieving euthyroid state.

questions.text: Osmotic demyelination syndrome (ODS) is brain cell dysfunction. It is caused by the destruction of the layer (myelin sheath) covering nerve cells in the middle of the brainstem. All are true about osmotic demyelination syndrome EXCEPT?

options.label: B
options.text: Lesions of ODS classically affect the Medulla

options.label: C
options.text: Associated with a disruption in the integrity of the blood-brain barrier

options.label: D
options.text: Entry of immune mediators contributes to demyelination

questions.correct_answer: B. Lesions of ODS classically affect the Medulla
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lesions of ODS classically affect the Medulla Hyponatremia with rapid correction leads to ODS. ODS (Osmotic Demyelination Syndrome) / CPM (Central pontine myelinolysis ODS (Mechanism)

Highyeild:

The lesions of ODS classically affect the pons. Clinically → Present 1 or more days after overcorrection of hyponatremia Paraparesis or quadri-paresis Dysphagia Dysarthria Diplopia, A “locked-in syndrome” Loss of consciousness.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Hypertonic stress in astrocytes within brain regions prone to ODS leads to Overly rapid correction of hyponatremia (>8–10 mM in 24 h or 18 mM in 48 h) Generalized protein ubiquitination Endoplasmic reticulum stress due to activation of the unfolded protein Response. Options: C and D. Disruption in the integrity of the blood-brain barrier, allowing the entry of immune mediators that may contribute to demyelination.

Extraedge:

Other regions of the brain can also be involved in ODS, most commonly in order of frequency: Cerebellum Lateral geniculate body Thalamus Putamen, and Cerebral cortex or sub-cortex. MRI Brain (FLAIR sequence) à Hyperintensities in the region of the pons

questions.text: Osmotic demyelination syndrome occurs due to a depleted adaptive process to protect against brain swelling, the redistribution of solutes with correction of hyponatremia causes brain shrinkage, which leads to disruption of tight junctions and disruption of the blood-brain barrier. Which is the most common site of lesion of extra pontine myelinolysis in isolation?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cerebellum Hyponatremia with rapid correction leads to ODS. ODS (Osmotic Demyelination Syndrome) / CPM (Central pontine myelinolysis The lesions of ODS classically affect the pons.

Highyeild:

Clinically → Present 1 or more days after overcorrection of hyponatremia Paraparesis or quadri-paresis Dysphagia Dysarthria Diplopia, A “locked-in syndrome Loss of consciousness

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: D. Other regions of the brain can also be involved in ODS, most commonly in order of frequency: Cerebellum Option: A. Lateral geniculate body ( 2 nd frequent cause) Thalamus Putamen, and Cerebral cortex or sub-cortex

questions.text: What is the LIKELY change in plasma Na+ concentration with every 100-mg/dL increase in glucose?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Falls by ~1.6-2.4 mM In hyponatremia, serum glucose should always be measured . Hyperglycemia is one of the causes of hyponatremia For every 100 mg/dL increase in glucose – Plasma Na+ concentration falls by ~1.6–2.4 mM This fall is due to glucose-induced water efflux from cells This is “true” hyponatremia It resolves after the correction of hyperglycemia

Highyeild:

Elevated BUN and creatinine indicate renal dysfunction as a potential cause of hyponatremia.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. B: Falls with the rise in Glucose. Option: D. 1.6-2.4 mM.

questions.text: Beer potomania, a unique syndrome of hyponatremia, was first reported in 1972. It is described as the excessive intake of alcohol, particularly beer, together with a poor dietary solute intake that leads to fatigue, dizziness, and muscular weakness. Patients with beer Potomania have a very high risk of developing ODS, due to the all EXCEPT?

options.label: D
options.text: High risk of overcorrecting the plasma Na+ concentration

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hyperkalemia Beer potomania (Low solute intake) Occurs in alcoholics whose sole nutrient is beer. Beer is very low in protein and salt content ( 1–2 mM of Na) AVP levels are suppressed or rapidly suppressible with saline hydration. The resumption of a normal diet and/or saline hydration will correct the causative deficit. Patients with additional risk factors prone to develop ODS ( Whether by rapid correction or even slow correction of Na) Alcoholism Malnutrition Hypokalemia Liver transplantation

Highyeild:

Beer potomania typically presents with a very low urine osmolality <100–200 mOsm/kg Urine Na+ < 10 – 20 Mm

Extraedge:

The syndrome has also been described in non-alcoholic patients with highly restricted solute intake (Nutrient-restricted diets like extreme vegetarian diets)

questions.text: For serious symptomatic hyponatremia, the first line of treatment is prompt intravenous infusion of hypertonic saline. Which of the following is true about the rate of correction in chronic hyponatremia?

options.label: A
options.text: Less than 4-5 mM in the first 24 h and Less than 10 mM in the first 48 h

options.label: B
options.text: Less than 4-5 mM in the first 24 h and Less than 18 mM in the first 48 h

options.label: C
options.text: Less than 8-10 mM in the first 24 h and Less than 18 mM in the first 48 h

options.label: D
options.text: Less than 8-10 mM in the first 24 h and Less than 28 mM in the first 48 h

questions.correct_answer: C. Less than 8-10 mM in the first 24 h and Less than 18 mM in the first 48 h
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Less than 8-10 mM in the first 24 h and Less than 18 mM in the first 48 h Symptomatology s/o severe hyponatremia (whether acute or chronic) Treatment with hypertonic saline is essential in symptomatic patients. Treatment with hypertonic 3% saline in acute hyponatremia 3% NS contains 513mM of Na and Cl. As an infusion : Increase plasma Na+ concentration by 1–2 mM/h to a total of 4–6 Mm As bolus : 100 mL of hypertonic saline rapidly improves both serum sodium and mental status. Treatment in chronic hyponatremia There is an asymmetry in the cellular response to the correction of plasma Na+. Re-accumulation of organic osmolytes by brain cells is attenuated and delayed as osmolality increases after correction of hyponatremia, sometimes resulting in degenerative loss of oligodendrocytes and an osmotic demyelination syndrome ( ODS ). Range of correction of hyponatremia < 8–10 mM in 24 h or < 18 mM in 48 h

Highyeild:

Na+ deficit = 0.6 × body weight × (target plasma Na+ concentration – starting plasma Na+ concentration) Plasma Na+ concentration should be monitored every 2–4 h

Extraedge:

3% NS bolus is more effective than infusion Type of respiratory failure seen: Hypercapnic respiratory failure

questions.text: A patient with acute hypernatremia (less than 48 h) due to sodium loading can be safely corrected at?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Upto 1 mM/h Hypernatremia → increase in the plasma Na+ concentration to >145 mM Combined water and electrolyte deficit, with losses of H2O in excess of Na+. Hypernatremia should be corrected slowly to avoid cerebral edema. Replace the calculated free water deficit over 48 h . Plasma Na+ concentration should be corrected by no more than 10 mM /d Treatment: Electrolyte-free water is administered by mouth or by nasogastric tube. IV 5% dextrose (D5W) (Monitor RBS) If dehydrated/low volume à IV ½ NS or ¼ NS Treatment of Acute hypernatremia (Due to sodium loading) Rapid correction at a rate of 1mM/hr.

Highyeild:

The Free water deficit is the amount of free water a patient has lost. Calculated by: [(Na+ – 140)/140] × TBW Total-body water (TBW) à 50% of body weight in women and 60% in men.

questions.text: Thyrotoxic periodic paralysis is a condition in which there are episodes of severe muscle weakness. It occurs in people who have high levels of thyroid hormone in their blood. Which of the following can be the associated electrolyte abnormality in thyrotoxic periodic paralysis [TPP]?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hypokalemia Thyrotoxic periodic paralysis (TPP) Periodic attacks of paralysis Typically presenting with weakness of the extremities and limb girdles Most frequently between 1 and 6 a.m Due to Redistributive hypokalemia Hypokalemia is defined as a plasma K+ < 3.5 mM Signs and symptoms of hyperthyroidism are not invariably present.

Highyeild:

Accompanied by hypophosphatemia and hypomagnesemia .

Extraedge:

Genetic predisposition has also been linked to variation in the 6 K+ channel. Pathophysiology: Increased Na+/K+-ATPase activity Increased circulating insulin Reduced KIR channel current

questions.text: Which of the following familial hyperaldosteronism is due to mutations in the KCNJ5 gene, which encodes the G-protein activated inward rectifier K+ channel 4 (GIRK4)?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

FH-III Hyperaldosteronism (Increased circulatory aldosterone) may be primary or secondary. Primary hyperaldosteronism may be genetic or acquired Major forms of isolated primary genetic hyperaldosteronism are: FH-I (familial hyperaldosteronism type I) FH-II (type II) FH-III (Type III) Aldosterone activates the ENaC channel in principal cells thus increasing the driving force for K+ excretion. FH-III is caused by mutations in the KCNJ5 gene , which encodes the GIRK4 (G protein–activated inward rectifier K+ channel 4)

Highyeild:

FH-I, also known as glucocorticoid-remediable hyperaldosteronism ( GRA ) FH-I is caused by a chimeric gene duplication between the homologous 11β-hydroxylase (CYP11B1) and aldosterone synthase (CYP11B2) genes.

Extraedge:

Chimeric gene in FH-I is under the control of ACTH and thus repressible by glucocorticoids.

questions.text: In the absence of abnormal K+ redistribution, the total deficit correlates with serum K+, such that for every 100 mmol reductions in total-body stores, serum K+ changes by?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Drops by ~0.27 mM Oral replacement with K+-Cl– is the mainstay of therapy in hypokalemia The deficit of K+ and the rate of correction should be estimated as accurately as possible The risk of overcorrection depends on Renal function Medications Comorbid conditions such as diabetes In the absence of abnormal K+ redistribution, the total deficit correlates with serum K+ For every 100 mmol reductions in total-body stores, serum K+ drops by 0.27 mM Loss of 400–800 mmol of total-body K+ results in a reduction in serum K+ by 2.0 mM The deficit must be replaced gradually over 24–48 h

Highyeild:

K+phosphate is given in → combined hypokalemia and hypophosphatemia. K+bicarbonate or potassium citrate given in → concomitant metabolic acidosis .

Extraedge:

Hypomagnesemia patients are refractory to K+ replacement alone. Concomitant Mg2+ deficiency should always be corrected first.

questions.text: Hypokalemia is treated with oral or intravenous potassium. To prevent cardiac conduction disturbances, intravenous calcium is administered to patients with hyperkalemia electrocardiogram changes. Which vessel is preferable for Intravenous K+-Cl- in hypokalemia treatment?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Femoral vein Indication of intravenous administration of KCl in hypokalemia: Patients unable to use the enteral route Severe complications (e.g., paralysis, arrhythmia). The peripheral veins are preferred. The peripheral intravenous dose is usually 20–40 mmo l of KCl per liter Higher concentrations can cause localized pain from chemical phlebitis, irritation, and sclerosis Indication of the central intravenous route of administration of KCl: Severe hypokalemia (<2.5Mm/L) Critically symptomatic patients Rate of 10 – 20 mM/hr Cardiac monitoring in an intensive care setting is mandatory as the local concentration of K+ affects cardiac conduction

Highyeild:

IV KCl should always be administered in saline solutions (A dextrose-induced increase in insulin can acutely exacerbate hypokalemia). The absolute amount of administered K+ should be restricted (e.g ., 20 mmol in 100 mL of saline solution ) to prevent inadvertent infusion of a large dose

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A, B: Acutely increase the local concentration of K+ and affect cardiac conduction. Option: C: Venous route is preferred.

questions.text: Which of the following is an INCORRECT match for ECG changes with respective concentrations of serum potassium?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Narrowed QRS complex (7.0-8.0 mM) Hyperkalemia is defined as a plasma K of 5.5 mM Severe hyperkalemia > 6.0 mM

Highyeild:

These changes are notoriously insensitive in patients with chronic kidney disease or ESRD. Severe hyperkalemia results in the loss of the P wave and a progressive widening of the QRS complex

Extraedge:

Development of a sine-wave sino-ventricular rhythm suggests impending ventricular fibrillation or asystole

questions.text: Which of the following has no role in the immediate management of hyperkalemia but may slowly attenuate hyperkalemia?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

IV bicarbonate Treatment of Hyperkalemia IV calcium (gluconate or chloride) Insulin plus dextrose Nebulisation with β2 –agonists (albuterol) Cation exchange resins Diuretics Dialysis Intravenous bicarbonate No role in the acute treatment of hyperkalemia Infused in an isotonic or hypotonic fluid (e.g., 150 mEq in 1 L of D5W) Slowly attenuates hyperkalemia with sustained administration over several hours. In patients with metabolic acidosis, a delayed drop in plasma K+ concentration can be seen after 4–6 h of isotonic bicarbonate infusion

Highyeild:

Bicarbonate should not be given repeatedly as a hypertonic intravenous bolus of undiluted ampules due to the risk of associated hypernatremia

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Insulin lowers plasma K+ concentration by shifting K+ into cells. Option: C. Intravenous calcium serves to protect the heart, whereas other measures are taken to correct hyperkalemia. Option: D. β2-agonists, most commonly albuterol, are effective but underused agents for the acute management of hyperkalemia.

questions.text: What changes in corrected calcium concentration need to be done with every decrement in serum albumin of 1.0 g/dL below the reference value of 4.1 g/dL for albumin?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Add 0.2 mM (0.8 mg/dL) The first step in the diagnostic evaluation of hyper- or hypocalcemia is to ensure that the alteration in serum calcium levels is not due to abnormal albumin concentrations. About 50% of total calcium is ionized, and the rest is bound principally to albumin. Preferable to measure total calcium and albumin to “correct” the serum calcium. When serum albumin concentrations are reduced, a corrected calcium concentration is calculated by: Adding 0.2 mM (0.8 mg/dL) to the total calcium level for every decrement in - serum albumin of 1.0 g/dL below the reference value of 4.1 g/dL for albumin Formula: Corrected Ca = Measure total Ca + 0.8 (4.1 – measured serum albumin)

Highyeild:

Direct measurements of ionized calcium are possible but they are easily influenced by collection methods and other artifacts.

questions.text: A named sign is observable as a carpopedal spasm induced by ischemia secondary to the inflation of a sphygmomanometer cuff, commonly on an individual's arm. Which of the following is true about this sign?

options.label: A
options.text: Seen in Hypercalcemia by inflation of a blood pressure cuff to 20 mmHg for 3 min

options.label: B
options.text: Seen in Hypercalcemia by inflation of a blood pressure cuff to 20 mmHg above the patient's systolic blood pressure for 3 min

options.label: C
options.text: Seen in Hypocalcemia by inflation of a blood pressure cuff to 20 mmHg for 3 min

options.label: D
options.text: Seen in Hypocalcemia by inflation of a blood pressure cuff to 20 mmHg above the patient's systolic blood pressure for 3 min

questions.correct_answer: D. Seen in Hypocalcemia by inflation of a blood pressure cuff to 20 mmHg above the patient's systolic blood pressure for 3 min
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Seen in Hypocalcemia by inflation of a blood pressure cuff to 20 mmHg above the patient's systolic blood pressure for 3 min Carpal spasm / carpopedal spasm is a feature of hypocalcemia Clinical manifestations of hypocalcemia: Asymptomatic Paresthesias Carpopedal spasms Chvostek’s sign Seizures Bronchospasm Laryngospasm QT prolongation Inflation of a blood pressure cuff to 20 mmHg above the patient’s systolic blood pressure for 3 min induce – Carpal spasms

Highyeild:

Paresthesias in fingers, toes and circumoral regions Chvostek’s sign - twitching of the circumoral muscles in response to gentle tapping of the facial nerve just anterior to the ear

Extraedge:

Chvostek’s sign is seen in 10 % of normal individuals. Response to inflation test in the form of carpal spasm is → Trousseau’s sign
